<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>

Here is the code of UtAssertEx:

```c
bool UtAssertEx(bool Expression, UtAssert_CaseType_t CaseType, const char *File, uint32 Line, const char *MessageFormat,
                ...)
{
    va_list va;
    char    FinalMessage[256];
    uint32  TestSegmentCount;
    uint32  TotalTestCases;

    UT_BSP_Lock();

    ++UT_SegmentCounters.TotalTestCases;

    if (Expression)
    {
        CaseType = UTASSERT_CASETYPE_PASS;
    }

    if ((uint32)CaseType < UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MAX)
    {
        ++UT_SegmentCounters.CaseCount[(uint32)CaseType];
    }

    TestSegmentCount = 1 + UT_TotalCounters.TestSegmentCount;
    TotalTestCases   = UT_SegmentCounters.TotalTestCases;

    UT_BSP_Unlock();

    va_start(va, MessageFormat);
    vsnprintf(FinalMessage, sizeof(FinalMessage), MessageFormat, va);
    va_end(va);

    UtAssert_DoReport(File, Line, TestSegmentCount, TotalTestCases, CaseType, CurrentSegment, FinalMessage);

    return Expression;
}
```

void UtAssert_DoReport(const char *File, uint32 LineNum, uint32 SegmentNum, uint32 TestSeq, uint8 MessageType,
                       const char *SubsysName, const char *ShortDesc)
{
    uint32      FileLen;
    const char *BasePtr;
    char        ReportBuffer[320];

    FileLen = strlen(File);
    BasePtr = File + FileLen;
    while (FileLen > 0)
    {
        --BasePtr;
        --FileLen;
        if (*BasePtr == '/' || *BasePtr == '\\')
        {
            ++BasePtr;
            break;
        }
    }

    snprintf(ReportBuffer, sizeof(ReportBuffer), "%02u.%03u %s:%u - %s", (unsigned int)SegmentNum,
             (unsigned int)TestSeq, BasePtr, (unsigned int)LineNum, ShortDesc);

    UT_BSP_DoText(MessageType, ReportBuffer);
}
...
void UT_BSP_DoText(uint8 MessageType, const char *OutputMessage)
{
    char   Buffer[16];
    size_t MsgLen;
    uint32 TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL;
    uint32 MsgEnabled   = BSP_UT_Global.CurrVerbosity >> MessageType;

    if (MsgEnabled & 1)
    {
        UT_BSP_Lock();

        /* Determine if the message type warrants special treatment (color/highlight/etc). */
        switch (MessageType)
        {
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT:
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_RED;
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MIR:
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_WARN:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_RED | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_GREEN;
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TSF:
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TTF:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_RED | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_BLUE;
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_BEGIN:
                OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl("\n", 1); /* add a bit of extra whitespace between tests */
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_PASS:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_GREEN;
                break;
            default:
                break;
        }

        if (MsgEnabled <= 1)
        {
            TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL;
        }

        snprintf(Buffer, sizeof(Buffer), "[%5s]", UtAssert_GetCaseTypeAbbrev(MessageType));

        if (TermModeBits != OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL)
        {
            OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl(TermModeBits);
        }

        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(Buffer, strlen(Buffer));

        if (TermModeBits != OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL)
        {
            OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl(OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL);
        }

        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(" ", 1);
        MsgLen = strlen(OutputMessage);
        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(OutputMessage, MsgLen);
        if (MsgLen == 0 || OutputMessage[MsgLen - 1] != '\n')
        {
            OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl("\n", 1);
        }

        UT_BSP_Unlock();
    }

    /*
     * If any ABORT (major failure) message is thrown,
     * then call a BSP-provided routine to stop the test and possibly dump a core
     */
    if (MessageType == UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT)
    {
        OS_BSP_Shutdown_Impl();
    }
}

explanation:
The fragments selected are the locations where standard string functions (strlen) or formatted string output (vsnprintf/snprintf) operate on or read strings that may originate externally or be user-supplied. These are the spots that could result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters if the input pointers are not valid or not NUL-terminated as expected; they therefore warrant investigation.

Other code in the snippets does not need to be investigated for Rule 21.17 based on the provided context because:
- Local destination buffers are written using snprintf/vsnprintf with their size provided via sizeof(buffer). These calls (when conforming to the C standard implementation) limit the written characters to the buffer size and ensure NUL-termination, so they do not by themselves imply out-of-bounds reads of source strings inside this code fragment set.
- Literal strings and explicit-length console output calls (e.g., OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl("\n", 1)) do not perform any string scanning and are safe with respect to this rule.
- Lock/unlock and counter increments do not involve string handling and are irrelevant to Rule 21.17.

The flagged fragments concentrate on places where strlen is called on pointers that may be external (File, OutputMessage) and where the code subsequently indexes or uses the computed lengths; these are the highest-risk locations for potential out-of-bounds accesses and should be examined further.
